ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the input data set. The input data set must be sorted by cross section and by time 
period within cross section. If you omit the DATA= option, the most recently created SAS 
data set is used.

[Syntax: OUTEST=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names an output data set to contain the parameter estimates. When the OUTEST= option 
is not specified, the OUTEST= data set is not created.

[Syntax: OUTTRANS=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names an output data set to contain the transformed series for further analysis and 
computation of models with time observations greater than two.
Writes the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set.
Writes the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates to the OUTEST= data set.

[Syntax: PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> < = (specific-plot-options)>] 
      
Requests that the PANEL procedure produce statistical graphics via the Output Delivery System, 
provided that the ODS GRAPHICS statement has been specified. The global plot options 
supported by the PANEL procedure are:

  ONLY 
  suppresses the default plots. Only the plots specifically requested are produced. 

  UNPACK|UNPACKPANEL 
  breaks a graphic that is otherwise paneled into individual component plots.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Produces surface plot of actual values.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Plots the predicted and actual values.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Produces surface plot of predicted values.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Produces a stacked plot of residuals.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Produces surface plot of residual values.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that a between-groups model be estimated.
Specifies that a between-time-periods model be estimated.
Prints the matrix of estimated correlations between the parameter estimates.
Prints the matrix of estimated covariances between the parameter estimates.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Da Silva method, which assumes a mixed 
variance-component moving-average model for the error structure.
Suppresses the intercept parameter from the model.

Specifies that a one-way fixed-effects model be estimated with the one-way model corresponding 
to cross-sectional effects only.

Specifies that a one-way fixed-effects model be estimated with the one-way model corresponding 
to time effects only.
Specifies that a two-way fixed-effects model be estimated.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Fuller-Battese method, which assumes a 
variance components model for the error structure.

[Syntax: M=number] 
      
Specifies the order of the moving-average process in the Da Silva method. 
The value of the M=option must be less than T-1. The default is M=1.
Suppresses the normal printed output.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Parks method, which assumes a first-order 
autoregressive model for the error structure.

Prints the Φ matrix of estimated covariances of the observations for the Parks method. The PHI 
option is relevant only when the PARKS option is used.
Specifies that a pooled (OLS) model be estimated.
Specifies that a one-way random-effects model be estimated.
Specifies that a two-way random-effects model be estimated.
Prints the estimated autocorrelation coefficients for the Parks method.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
      
Specifies a singularity criterion for the inversion of the matrix. The default depends on the 
precision of the computer system.

Specifies the type of variance component estimate to use. The default is VCOMP=FB for balanced 
data and VCOMP=WK for unbalanced data.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Uses the Fuller and Battese method for estimating variance components.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses the Nerlove method for estimating variance components.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Uses the Wallace and Hussain method for estimating variance components.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Uses the Wansbeek and Kapteyn method for estimating variance components.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY variables ; 

A BY statement can be used with PROC PANEL to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups 
defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the input data set must be sorted by the 
BY variables as well as by cross section and time period within the BY groups.

Syntax: CLASS variables </ OUT= SAS-data-set> ; 

The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used in the analysis. Classification variables
can be either character or numeric. 

In PROC PANEL, the CLASS statement enables you to output class variables to a data set that contains a copy
of the original data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: out= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.

[Syntax: BASE=(variable, variable, ..., variable)] 
          
Specifies the variables that are to be transformed into a proper PROC PANEL format. All 
variables to be transformed must be named according to the convention: basename_timeperiod. 
You supply just the basename, and the procedure extracts the appropriate variables to transform. 
If some year’s data are missing for a variable, then PROC PANEL detects this and fills in with 
missing values.

[Syntax: INDID=variable] 
          
Names the variable in the input data set that uniquely identifies each individual. The INDID 
variable can be a character or numeric variable.

[Syntax: KEEP=(variable, variable, ..., variable)] 
          
Specifies the variables that are to be copied without any transformation. These variables 
remain constant with respect to time when the data are converted to PROC PANEL format. This 
is an optional item.

[Syntax: TSNAME=name] 
          
Specifies a name for the generated time identifier. The name must satisfy the requirements 
for the name of a SAS variable. The name can be quoted, but it must not be the name of a 
variable in the input data set.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Saves the converted flat data set to a PROC PANEL formatted data set.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ID cross-section-id time-series-id ; 

The ID statement is used to specify variables in the input data set that identify the cross 
section and time period for each observation. 

When an ID statement is used, the PANEL procedure verifies that the input data set is sorted 
by the cross section ID variable and by the time series ID variable within each cross section. 
The PANEL procedure also verifies that the time series ID values are the same for all cross 
sections. Use PROC SORT to sort the input data set with a BY statement with the variables listed 
exactly as they are listed in the ID statement

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Includes an intercept (column of ones) as an uncorrelated exogenous instrument.
Specifies that a dependent variable be used at an appropriate lag as an instrument.

[Syntax: CORRELATED=(variable, variable, ..., variable)] 
          
Specifies a list of variables correlated with the error term. These variables are not used 
in forming moment conditions from level equations.

[Syntax: EXOGENOUS=(variable, variable, ..., variable)] 
          
Specifies a list of variables that are not correlated with the error term.

[Syntax: PREDETERMINED=(variable, variable, ..., variable)] 
          
Specifies a list of variables whose future realizations can be correlated with the error term 
but whose present and past realizations are not. 

If a variable listed in the EXOGENOUS list is not included in the CORRELATED list, then it is 
considered to be uncorrelated to the error term.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: LAG var(   ... ) , ..., var(   ... ) < / OUT= SAS-data-set > ; 
      
Generally, creating lags of variables in a panel setting is a tedious process in which you 
must generate many DATA STEP statements. The PANEL procedure now enables you to generate lags 
of any series without jumping across any individual’s boundary. The lag statement is a data 
set generation tool.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.  The output data set includes all variables in the input set, 
plus the lags that are denoted with the convention originalvar_lag.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CLAG var(   ... ) , ..., var(   ... ) < / OUT= SAS-data-set > ; 
      
Replaces missing values with the cross section mean for that variable in that cross section. 
Note that missing values are replaced only if they are in the generated (lagged) series. 
Missing variables in the original variables are not changed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.  The output data set includes all variables in the input set, 
plus the lags that are denoted with the convention originalvar_lag.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SLAG var(   ... ) , ..., var(   ... ) < / OUT= SAS-data-set > ; 
      
Replaces missing values with the time mean for that variable in that time period. Note that 
missing values are replaced only if they are in the generated (lagged) series. Missing variables 
in the original variables are not changed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.  The output data set includes all variables in the input set, 
plus the lags that are denoted with the convention originalvar_lag.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: XLAG var(   ... ) , ..., var(   ... ) < / OUT= SAS-data-set > ; 
      
Replaces missing values with the overall mean for that variable. Note that missing values are 
replaced only if they are in the generated (lagged) series. Missing variables in the original 
variables are not changed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.  The output data set includes all variables in the input set, 
plus the lags that are denoted with the convention originalvar_lag.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ZLAG var(   ... ) , ..., var(   ... ) < / OUT= SAS-data-set > ; 
      
Replaces missing values with zero for that variable. Note that missing values are replaced only 
if they are in the generated (lagged) series. Missing variables in the original variables are 
not changed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT= SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the output data set.  The output data set includes all variables in the input set, 
plus the lags that are denoted with the convention originalvar_lag.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: <label:> MODEL response = regressors </ options> ; 

The MODEL statement specifies the regression model and the error structure assumed for the 
regression residuals. The response variable on the left side of the equal sign is regressed 
on the independent variables listed after the equal sign. Any number of MODEL statements can 
be used. For each model statement, only one response variable can be specified on the left 
side of the equal sign.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ARTEST=integer] 
          
Specifies the maximum order of the test for the presence of AR effects in the residual. 
The acceptable range of values for this option is 1 to t-3.

[Syntax: ATOL=number] 
          
Specifies the convergence criterion for iterated GMM when convergence of the method is determined 
by convergence in the weighting matrix. The convergence criterion must be positive.
Specifies which observations are included in the instrument list when the MAXBAND option is employed.
Requests the Breusch-Pagan one-way test for random effects.
Requests the Breusch-Pagan two-way test for random effects.

[Syntax: BTOL=number] 
          
Specifies the convergence criterion for iterated GMM when convergence of the method is determined 
by convergence in the parameter matrix. The convergence criterion must be positive. The default is 
BTOL=1e–8.
Specifies that a between-groups model be estimated.
Specifies that a between-time-periods model be estimated.
Prints the matrix of estimated correlations between the parameter estimates.
Prints the matrix of estimated covariances between the parameter estimates.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Da Silva method, which assumes a mixed 
variance-component moving-average model for the error structure.

Specifies that a one-way fixed-effects model be estimated with the one-way model corresponding 
to cross-sectional effects only.

Specifies that a one-way fixed-effects model be estimated with the one-way model corresponding 
to time effects only.
Specifies that a two-way fixed-effects model be estimated.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Fuller-Battese method, which assumes 
a variance components model for the error structure.
Specifies what type of generalized inverse to use. The default is a G2 inverse.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: G2 inverse. This is the default.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the model be estimated by using the dynamic panel estimator method, which 
allows for autoregressive processes. This is the single-step model.

[Syntax: HCCME=number] 
          
Specifies the type of HCCME variance-covariance matrix requested. The expected range of values 
is no or 0 to 4. The default is zero, no correction.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the dynamic panel estimator method, but that 
PROC PANEL keep updating the weighting matrix until either the parameter vector converges 
or the weighting matrix converges.
Prints out the iteration history of the parameter and transformed sum of error squared.

[Syntax: M=number] 
          
Specifies the order of the moving-average process in the Da Silva method. The value of the 
M=option must be less than . The default is M=1.

[Syntax: MAXBAND=integer] 
          
Specifies the maximum number of time periods (per instrumental variable) that are allowed into 
the moment condition. The acceptable range of values for this option is 1 to t-1. The default 
value is MAXBAND=1 or MAXBAND=2, depending on the BANDOPT option.

[Syntax: MAXITER= integer] 
          
Specifies the maximum number of iterations allowed for the iterated GMM option. The default 
value is MAXITER=200.

Specifies that the dynamic panel model be estimated without moment conditions from the 
difference equations.

Limits the estimation of a FIXONE, FIXONETIME, RANONE model to the generation of the transformed 
series. This option is intended for use with an OUTTRANS= data set.
Suppresses the intercept parameter from the model.

Specifies that the dynamic panel model be estimated without moment conditions from the 
level equations.
Suppresses the normal printed output.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the Parks method, which assumes a first-order 
autoregressive model for the error structure.

Prints the Φ matrix of estimated covariances of the observations for the Parks method. The PHI 
option is relevant only when the PARKS option is used.
Specifies that a pooled (OLS) model be estimated.
Specifies that a one-way random-effects model be estimated.
Specifies that a two-way random-effects model be estimated.
Prints the estimated autocorrelation coefficients for the Parks method.

Specifies that robust weighting matrix be used in the calculation of the variance-covariance 
matrix of the single step estimator.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
          
Specifies a singularity criterion for the inversion of the matrix. The default depends on the 
precision of the computer system.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the dynamic panel estimator method, but that 
PROC PANEL includes time dummy variables to model any time effects present in the data.

Specifies that the model be estimated by using the dynamic panel estimator method, but that 
two steps be used in the estimation. An initial first step is used to form an estimator for 
the weighting matrix used in the second step.

Specifies the type of variance component estimate to use. The default is VCOMP=FB for balanced 
data and VCOMP=WK for unbalanced data.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Uses the Fuller and Battese method for estimating variance components.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses the Nerlove method for estimating variance components.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Uses the Wallace and Hussain method for estimating variance components.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Uses the Wansbeek and Kapteyn method for estimating variance components.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUTPUT OUT=SAS-data-set < = options ...> ; 

The OUTPUT statement creates an output SAS data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Names the output SAS data set to contain the predicted and transformed values. If the OUT= 
option is not specified, the new data set is named according to the DATAn convention.

[Syntax: PREDICTED=name] 
          
Writes the predicted values to the output data set.

[Syntax: RESIDUAL=name] 
          
Writes the residuals from the predicted values based on both the structural and time series 
parts of the model to the output data set.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: RESTRICT "string" equation <,equation2...> ; 

The RESTRICT statement specifies linear equality restrictions on the parameters in the 
previous model statement. There can be as many unique restrictions as the number of 
parameters in the preceding model statement. Multiple RESTRICT statements are understood 
as joint restrictions on a model’s parameters. Restrictions on the intercept are obtained 
by the use of the keyword INTERCEPT.

Syntax: TEST "string" equation <,equation2...>< / options> ; 

The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier and likelihood ratio tests of linear 
hypotheses about the regression parameters in the preceding MODEL statement. Each equation 
specifies a linear hypothesis to be tested. All hypotheses in one TEST statement are tested 
jointly. Variable names in the equations must correspond to regressors in the preceding MODEL 
statement, and each name represents the coefficient of the corresponding regressor. The keyword 
INTERCEPT refers to the coefficient of the intercept.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies Wald, Lagrange multiplier and likelihood ratio tests.
Specifies the WALD test.
Specifies the Lagrange multiplier test.
Specifies the likelihood ratio test.
